triples.statement: In 2014, DC's chief creative officer Geoff Johns stated that the TV series "Arrow" and "The Flash" were in a separate universe from the new film universe, later clarifying this concept as a multiverse.

triples.sentence: It's like he knows what he needs to do but can't focus on the task at hand. TV certainly isn't immune to that problem, but shows that get caught up in high-concept premises and big-picture thinking before doing the necessary legwork to establish characters and their relationships tend to be canceled."[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VoxCivilWarTV-318)
triples.statement: Emily St. James compared Zack Snyder's approach to television shows that are often canceled for focusing on high-concept ideas before properly establishing characters and their relationships.

triples.sentence: The two were made producers on the _Justice League_ films, on top of Johns' involvement in several "solo" films, such as the post-production process of _[Suicide Squad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suicide\_Squad\_(2016\_film) "Suicide Squad (2016 film)")_ (2016) or the writing process of a standalone Batman film.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DCEUShakeUp-349)
triples.statement: Geoff Johns and Jon Berg were made producers on the Justice League films, with Johns also being involved in solo films like "Suicide Squad" and a standalone Batman movie.

triples.sentence: Moving forward, you'll see the DC movie universe being a universe, but one that comes from the heart of the filmmaker who's creating them." Additionally, DC began focusing on films "completely separate from everything else, set entirely outside" the DCEU as part of a new label, with [the first film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joker_(2019_film) "Joker (2019 film)") centered on the [Joker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joker_(character) "Joker (character)").[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VultureDCFilmsSep2017-350)
triples.statement: DC's new approach was to have a movie universe driven by filmmakers, and it also started a new label for films set entirely outside the DCEU, with the first being centered on the Joker.

triples.sentence: By July 2024, both Feige and Gunn had expressed interest in one day creating a crossover between the two franchises, though both noted it was not something actively being discussed or considered.[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FeigeGunnMarvelDCCrossover2024-354)
triples.statement: By July 2024, both Kevin Feige and James Gunn had shown interest in a future crossover between the Marvel and DC franchises, although they noted it was not under active discussion.

triples.sentence: However, Gunn noted there would have been "some pretty, pretty big [legal] hoops" to go through to accomplish this, and ultimately moved on from the idea.[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-PlannedDeadpoolPeacemakerCameo-355)
triples.statement: Gunn ultimately abandoned the idea of a Deadpool cameo in "Peacemaker" because of significant legal hurdles that would have been involved.

section_body:
Main articles: [X-Men (film series)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men_(film_series) "X-Men (film series)") and [Fantastic Four in film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantastic_Four_in_film "Fantastic Four in film")

In November 2012, 20th Century Fox announced plans to create its own shared universe of Marvel properties it held the rights to, including the Fantastic Four and X-Men, with the hiring of [Mark Millar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Millar "Mark Millar") as supervising producer. Millar said, "Fox are thinking, 'We're sitting on some really awesome things here. There is another side of the Marvel Universe. Let's try and get some cohesiveness going.' So they brought me in to oversee that really. To meet with the writers and directors to suggest new ways we could take this stuff and new properties that could spin out of it."[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SlashFilmNov2012-356)_[X-Men: Days of Future Past](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:\_Days\_of\_Future\_Past "X-Men: Days of Future Past")_, released in 2014, was Fox's first step towards expanding their stable of Marvel properties and creating this universe,[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNFoxSony-357) ahead of the release of a [_Fantastic Four_ reboot film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantastic_Four_(2015_film) "Fantastic Four (2015 film)") the next year.[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FantasticFour-358) In May 2014, _Days of Future Past_ and _Fantastic Four_ screenwriter [Simon Kinberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Kinberg "Simon Kinberg") stated that the latter film would not take place in the same universe as the _X-Men_ films, explaining that "none of the _X-Men_ movies have acknowledged the notion of a sort of superhero team—the Fantastic Four. And the Fantastic Four acquire powers, so for them to live in a world where mutants are prevalent is kind of complicated, because you're like, 'Oh, you're just a mutant.' Like, 'What's so fantastic about you?' ... they live in discrete universes."[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FantasticFour-358) In July 2015, _X-Men_ director [Bryan Singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryan_Singer "Bryan Singer") said that there was still potential for a crossover between the _X-Men_ and _Fantastic Four_ franchises, if reactions to _Fantastic Four_ and _[X-Men: Apocalypse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:\_Apocalypse "X-Men: Apocalypse")_ (2016) warranted it.[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SingerCrossover-359)

Feeling that Singer's efforts in _Apocalypse_ to establish a larger world, similar to the MCU, did not meet the standards established by Marvel, St. James noted that unlike Feige's ability to serve as "pseudo-showrunner", Singer is instead "steeped in film and the way movie stories have always been told", so "when it comes time to have _Apocalypse_ dovetail with story threads from the earlier _[X-Men: First Class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:\_First\_Class "X-Men: First Class")_", which was directed by [Matthew Vaughn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Vaughn "Matthew Vaughn"), "both Singer's direction and Simon Kinberg's script rely on hackneyed devices and clumsy storytelling", indicating a lack of "the kind of big-picture thinking this sort of mega franchise requires".[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VoxCivilWarTV-318) In his review of _[Dark Phoenix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark\_Phoenix\_(film) "Dark Phoenix (film)")_, Joe Morgenstern of _The Wall Street Journal_ characterized the entire X-Men film series as being a "notoriously erratic franchise".[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MorgensternDarkPhoenix-360) In March 2019, the film rights of Deadpool, the X-Men characters, and the Fantastic Four characters returned to Marvel Studios following the [acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_21st_Century_Fox_by_Disney "Acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney").[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FoxDisneyPressRelease-60)[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyFoxDealClose-61)

triples.sentence: Millar said, "Fox are thinking, 'We're sitting on some really awesome things here. There is another side of the Marvel Universe. Let's try and get some cohesiveness going.' So they brought me in to oversee that really. To meet with the writers and directors to suggest new ways we could take this stuff and new properties that could spin out of it."[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SlashFilmNov2012-356)
triples.statement: Mark Millar stated that Fox hired him to create cohesiveness and suggest new directions and spin-off properties for their side of the Marvel Universe.

triples.sentence: _[X-Men: Days of Future Past](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:_Days_of_Future_Past "X-Men: Days of Future Past")_, released in 2014, was Fox's first step towards expanding their stable of Marvel properties and creating this universe,[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNFoxSony-357) ahead of the release of a [_Fantastic Four_ reboot film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantastic_Four_(2015_film) "Fantastic Four (2015 film)") the next year.[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FantasticFour-358)
triples.statement: The 2014 film "X-Men: Days of Future Past" was 20th Century Fox's first step in creating its shared universe, preceding the release of a "Fantastic Four" reboot the following year.

triples.sentence: In May 2014, _Days of Future Past_ and _Fantastic Four_ screenwriter [Simon Kinberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Kinberg "Simon Kinberg") stated that the latter film would not take place in the same universe as the _X-Men_ films, explaining that "none of the _X-Men_ movies have acknowledged the notion of a sort of superhero team—the Fantastic Four. And the Fantastic Four acquire powers, so for them to live in a world where mutants are prevalent is kind of complicated, because you're like, 'Oh, you're just a mutant.' Like, 'What's so fantastic about you?' ... they live in discrete universes."[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FantasticFour-358)
triples.statement: In May 2014, screenwriter Simon Kinberg stated that the "Fantastic Four" film would exist in a separate universe from the "X-Men" films, explaining that the concept of the Fantastic Four would be complicated in a world where mutants are already prevalent.

triples.sentence: In July 2015, _X-Men_ director [Bryan Singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryan_Singer "Bryan Singer") said that there was still potential for a crossover between the _X-Men_ and _Fantastic Four_ franchises, if reactions to _Fantastic Four_ and _[X-Men: Apocalypse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:_Apocalypse "X-Men: Apocalypse")_ (2016) warranted it.[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SingerCrossover-359)
triples.statement: In July 2015, director Bryan Singer indicated a potential crossover between the X-Men and Fantastic Four franchises was possible, depending on the audience reaction to "Fantastic Four" and "X-Men: Apocalypse".

triples.sentence: Feeling that Singer's efforts in _Apocalypse_ to establish a larger world, similar to the MCU, did not meet the standards established by Marvel, St. James noted that unlike Feige's ability to serve as "pseudo-showrunner", Singer is instead "steeped in film and the way movie stories have always been told", so "when it comes time to have _Apocalypse_ dovetail with story threads from the earlier _[X-Men: First Class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:_First_Class "X-Men: First Class")_", which was directed by [Matthew Vaughn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Vaughn "Matthew Vaughn"), "both Singer's direction and Simon Kinberg's script rely on hackneyed devices and clumsy storytelling", indicating a lack of "the kind of big-picture thinking this sort of mega franchise requires".[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VoxCivilWarTV-318)
triples.statement: St. James criticized Bryan Singer's efforts in "X-Men: Apocalypse" to build a larger world, suggesting that Singer's traditional filmmaking approach and the script's clumsy storytelling lacked the "big-picture thinking" necessary for a mega-franchise, unlike the MCU.

triples.sentence: In his review of _[Dark Phoenix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_Phoenix_(film) "Dark Phoenix (film)")_, Joe Morgenstern of _The Wall Street Journal_ characterized the entire X-Men film series as being a "notoriously erratic franchise".[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MorgensternDarkPhoenix-360)
triples.statement: In his review of "Dark Phoenix", Joe Morgenstern of The Wall Street Journal described the X-Men film series as a "notoriously erratic franchise".

triples.sentence: In March 2019, the film rights of Deadpool, the X-Men characters, and the Fantastic Four characters returned to Marvel Studios following the [acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_21st_Century_Fox_by_Disney "Acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney").[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-FoxDisneyPressRelease-60)[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyFoxDealClose-61)
triples.statement: In March 2019, the film rights for Deadpool, the X-Men, and the Fantastic Four returned to Marvel Studios after Disney's acquisition of 21st Century Fox.

section_body:
Main articles: [Spider-Man in film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man_in_film "Spider-Man in film") and [Sony's Spider-Man Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony%27s_Spider-Man_Universe "Sony's Spider-Man Universe")

See also: [List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films §Connections with other Spider-Man franchises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Connections_with_other_Spider-Man_franchises "List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films")

In November 2013, Sony Pictures Entertainment co-chairman [Amy Pascal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Pascal "Amy Pascal") announced that the studio intended to expand their universe created within director [Marc Webb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Webb "Marc Webb")'s [_The Amazing Spider-Man_ films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_(2012_film_series) "The Amazing Spider-Man (2012 film series)") (2012–14), with spin-off adventures for supporting characters, in an attempt to replicate Marvel and Disney's model.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNFoxSony-357) The next month, Sony announced [Venom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venom_(character) "Venom (character)") and [Sinister Six](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinister_Six "Sinister Six") films, both set in the _Amazing Spider-Man_ universe. With this announcement, _[IGN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IGN "IGN")_ stated that the spin-offs are "the latest example of what we can refer to as "the _Avengers_ effect" in Hollywood, as studios work to build interlocking movie universes."[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomSinisterSixIGN-361) Sony chose not to replicate the Marvel Studios model of introducing individual characters first before bringing them together in a team-up film, instead making the Spider-Man adversaries the stars of future films.[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ASM2EW-342) In February 2015, Sony Pictures and Marvel Studios announced that the _Spider-Man_ franchise would be retooled, with a new film co-produced by Feige and Pascal being released in July 2017, and the character being integrated into the MCU. Sony Pictures would continue to finance, distribute, own, and have final creative control of the _Spider-Man_ films.[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SpideyMCU-362) With this announcement, sequels to _[The Amazing Spider-Man 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Amazing\_Spider-Man\_2 "The Amazing Spider-Man 2")_ (2014) were canceled,[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpidey-363) and by November 2015 the Venom and Sinister Six films, as well as spin-offs based on female characters in the Spider-Man universe, were no longer moving forward.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpidey-363)[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SpideySpinoffs-364) By March 2016, the Venom film had itself been retooled, to start its own franchise unrelated to the MCU Spider-Man.[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomMar2016-365) A year later, Sony officially announced the Venom film to be in development, for an October 5, 2018, release,[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomMar2017-366) along with a film centered on the characters [Silver Sable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_Sable "Silver Sable") and [Black Cat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Cat_(Marvel_Comics) "Black Cat (Marvel Comics)") known as _[Silver & Black](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver\_%26\_Black\_(unproduced\_film) "Silver & Black (unproduced film)")_.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SilverSableBlackCat-367) Both projects were not intended to be a part of the MCU nor spin-offs to _Spider-Man: Homecoming_, but rather part of an intended separate shared universe known as the [Sony's Spider-Man Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony%27s_Spider-Man_Universe "Sony's Spider-Man Universe") (SSU).[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SilverSableBlackCat-367)[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomNotMCU-368)[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SSU-369) The [mid-credits scene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-credits_scene "Mid-credits scene") of _[Venom: Let There Be Carnage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venom:\_Let\_There\_Be\_Carnage "Venom: Let There Be Carnage")_ (2021) hinted at [Eddie Brock / Venom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venom_(Sony%27s_Spider-Man_Universe) "Venom (Sony's Spider-Man Universe)") joining the MCU,[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-LetThereBeCarnagePostCreditsScene-370) which was confirmed with the release of _[Spider-Man: No Way Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:\_No\_Way\_Home "Spider-Man: No Way Home")_ (2021) through an uncredited [cameo appearance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cameo_appearance "Cameo appearance") in its mid-credits scene.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-PostCreditsVenom-219)_Spider-Man: No Way Home_ also featured the [Spider-Man iterations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man_in_film "Spider-Man in film") from [Sam Raimi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Raimi "Sam Raimi") and Webb's _Spider-Man_ films, respectively reprised by [Tobey Maguire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobey_Maguire "Tobey Maguire") and [Andrew Garfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Garfield "Andrew Garfield").[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MaguireGarfieldSpiderManReprise-371)

After Sony canceled its shared universe plans and began sharing the Spider-Man character with Marvel Studios, multiple critics discussed its failure to replicate the MCU. Scott Meslow of _[The Week](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Week "The Week")_ noted the perceived flaws of the first _Amazing Spider-Man_ film, outside of its lead performances, and how the sequel "doubles down on all the missteps of the original while adding a few of its own. ...We now have a textbook example of how not to reboot a superhero franchise, and if Sony and Marvel are wise, they'll take virtually all those lessons to heart as they chart Spider-Man's next course."[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ASMWeek-372) Scott Mendelson noted that _The Amazing Spider-Man 2_ "was sold as less a sequel to _[The Amazing Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Amazing\_Spider-Man\_(2012\_film) "The Amazing Spider-Man (2012 film)")_ than a backdoor pilot for _Spider-Man vs. the Sinister Six_. ...Had Sony stuck with the original plan of a scaled-down superhero franchise, one that really was rooted in romantic drama, they would have at least stuck out in a crowded field of superhero franchises. When every superhero film is now going bigger, _Amazing Spider-Man_ could have distinguished itself by going small and intimate." This would have saved Sony "a boatload of money", and potentially reversed the film's relative financial failure.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ASMForbes-373)

triples.sentence: In November 2013, Sony Pictures Entertainment co-chairman [Amy Pascal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Pascal "Amy Pascal") announced that the studio intended to expand their universe created within director [Marc Webb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Webb "Marc Webb")'s [_The Amazing Spider-Man_ films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_(2012_film_series) "The Amazing Spider-Man (2012 film series)") (2012–14), with spin-off adventures for supporting characters, in an attempt to replicate Marvel and Disney's model.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNFoxSony-357)
triples.statement: In November 2013, Sony Pictures co-chairman Amy Pascal announced plans to expand the universe of Marc Webb's "The Amazing Spider-Man" films with spin-offs, aiming to replicate the model of Marvel and Disney.

triples.sentence: With this announcement, _[IGN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IGN "IGN")_ stated that the spin-offs are "the latest example of what we can refer to as "the _Avengers_ effect" in Hollywood, as studios work to build interlocking movie universes."[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomSinisterSixIGN-361)
triples.statement: Following Sony's announcement, IGN described the planned spin-offs as an example of "the Avengers effect," where studios attempt to create interconnected movie universes.

triples.sentence: Sony chose not to replicate the Marvel Studios model of introducing individual characters first before bringing them together in a team-up film, instead making the Spider-Man adversaries the stars of future films.[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ASM2EW-342)
triples.statement: Sony's strategy differed from Marvel Studios' by planning to feature Spider-Man's adversaries as the main characters in future films, rather than introducing them individually before a team-up.

triples.sentence: Sony Pictures would continue to finance, distribute, own, and have final creative control of the _Spider-Man_ films.[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SpideyMCU-362)
triples.statement: Under the new deal, Sony Pictures retained the rights to finance, distribute, own, and have final creative control over the Spider-Man films.

triples.sentence: With this announcement, sequels to _[The Amazing Spider-Man 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Amazing\_Spider-Man\_2 "The Amazing Spider-Man 2")_ (2014) were canceled,[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpidey-363) and by November 2015 the Venom and Sinister Six films, as well as spin-offs based on female characters in the Spider-Man universe, were no longer moving forward.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpidey-363)[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SpideySpinoffs-364)
triples.statement: Following the Sony-Marvel deal, sequels to "The Amazing Spider-Man 2" were canceled, and by November 2015, the planned Venom, Sinister Six, and female character spin-off films were also no longer in development.

triples.sentence: By March 2016, the Venom film had itself been retooled, to start its own franchise unrelated to the MCU Spider-Man.[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomMar2016-365)
triples.statement: By March 2016, the Venom film was retooled to launch its own franchise, separate from the MCU's Spider-Man.

triples.sentence: A year later, Sony officially announced the Venom film to be in development, for an October 5, 2018, release,[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomMar2017-366) along with a film centered on the characters [Silver Sable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_Sable "Silver Sable") and [Black Cat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Cat_(Marvel_Comics) "Black Cat (Marvel Comics)") known as _[Silver & Black](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver\_%26\_Black\_(unproduced\_film) "Silver & Black (unproduced film)")_.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SilverSableBlackCat-367)
triples.statement: A year later, Sony announced the Venom film was in development for an October 5, 2018 release, alongside a film titled "Silver & Black" featuring the characters Silver Sable and Black Cat.

triples.sentence: Both projects were not intended to be a part of the MCU nor spin-offs to _Spider-Man: Homecoming_, but rather part of an intended separate shared universe known as the [Sony's Spider-Man Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony%27s_Spider-Man_Universe "Sony's Spider-Man Universe") (SSU).[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SilverSableBlackCat-367)[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VenomNotMCU-368)[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SSU-369)
triples.statement: These projects were planned as part of a separate shared universe, Sony's Spider-Man Universe (SSU), and were not intended to be part of the MCU or spin-offs of "Spider-Man: Homecoming".

triples.sentence: The [mid-credits scene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-credits_scene "Mid-credits scene") of _[Venom: Let There Be Carnage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venom:_Let_There_Be_Carnage "Venom: Let There Be Carnage")_ (2021) hinted at [Eddie Brock / Venom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venom_(Sony%27s_Spider-Man_Universe) "Venom (Sony's Spider-Man Universe)") joining the MCU,[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-LetThereBeCarnagePostCreditsScene-370) which was confirmed with the release of _[Spider-Man: No Way Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_No_Way_Home "Spider-Man: No Way Home")_ (2021) through an uncredited [cameo appearance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cameo_appearance "Cameo appearance") in its mid-credits scene.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-PostCreditsVenom-219)
triples.statement: The mid-credits scene of "Venom: Let There Be Carnage" (2021) suggested Eddie Brock / Venom would join the MCU, a fact confirmed by an uncredited cameo in the mid-credits scene of "Spider-Man: No Way Home" (2021).

triples.sentence: _Spider-Man: No Way Home_ also featured the [Spider-Man iterations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man_in_film "Spider-Man in film") from [Sam Raimi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Raimi "Sam Raimi") and Webb's _Spider-Man_ films, respectively reprised by [Tobey Maguire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobey_Maguire "Tobey Maguire") and [Andrew Garfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Garfield "Andrew Garfield").[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MaguireGarfieldSpiderManReprise-371)
triples.statement: "Spider-Man: No Way Home" featured previous Spider-Man actors Tobey Maguire and Andrew Garfield reprising their roles from the Sam Raimi and Marc Webb film series.

triples.sentence: ...We now have a textbook example of how not to reboot a superhero franchise, and if Sony and Marvel are wise, they'll take virtually all those lessons to heart as they chart Spider-Man's next course."[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ASMWeek-372)
triples.statement: Meslow described the series as a "textbook example of how not to reboot a superhero franchise" and hoped Sony and Marvel would learn from its mistakes for Spider-Man's future.

triples.sentence: This would have saved Sony "a boatload of money", and potentially reversed the film's relative financial failure.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ASMForbes-373)
triples.statement: According to Mendelson, this different approach would have been more cost-effective for Sony and could have prevented the film's relative financial underperformance.

section_body: In September 2014, the [University of Baltimore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Baltimore "University of Baltimore") announced a course beginning in the 2015 [spring semester](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_term "Academic term") revolving around the Marvel Cinematic Universe, to be taught by Arnold T. Blumberg. "Media Genres: Media Marvels" examines "how Marvel's series of interconnected films and television shows, plus related media and comic book sources and [Joseph Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Campbell "Joseph Campbell")'s [monomyth of the 'hero's journey'](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monomyth "Monomyth"), offer important insights into modern culture" as well as Marvel's efforts "to establish a viable universe of plotlines, characters, and backstories."[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-UBaltCourse-374)[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-UBaltCourse2-375)

triples.sentence: "Media Genres: Media Marvels" examines "how Marvel's series of interconnected films and television shows, plus related media and comic book sources and [Joseph Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Campbell "Joseph Campbell")'s [monomyth of the 'hero's journey'](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monomyth "Monomyth"), offer important insights into modern culture" as well as Marvel's efforts "to establish a viable universe of plotlines, characters, and backstories."[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-UBaltCourse-374)[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-UBaltCourse2-375)
triples.statement: The course, titled "Media Genres: Media Marvels", examines how Marvel's interconnected media, along with Joseph Campbell's monomyth, provide insights into modern culture and Marvel's world-building efforts.

section_body:
Main article: [Avengers Campus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_Campus "Avengers Campus")

After the acquisition by Disney in 2009, Marvel films began to be marketed at the [Innoventions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innoventions_(Disneyland) "Innoventions (Disneyland)") attraction in [Tomorrowland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomorrowland_(Disney_Parks) "Tomorrowland (Disney Parks)") at [Disneyland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland"). For _Iron Man 3_, the exhibit, entitled "Iron Man Tech Presented by Stark Industries", featured the same armor display that was shown at the 2012 San Diego Comic-Con, with the Marks I-VII and the new Mark XLII. In addition, there was a simulator game, titled "Become Iron Man", that used [Kinect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinect "Kinect")-like technology to allow the viewer to be encased in an animated Mark XLII armor and take part in a series of "tests", in which you fire repulsor rays and fly through Tony Stark's workshop. The game was guided by J.A.R.V.I.S., who is voiced again by Paul Bettany. The exhibit also had smaller displays that included helmets and chest pieces from the earlier films and the gauntlet and boot from an action sequence in _Iron Man 3_.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IM3Disneyland-376) The exhibit for _Thor: The Dark World_ was called "Thor: Treasures of Asgard", and featured displays of [Asgardian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asgard_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Asgard (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") relics and transports guests to [Odin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odin_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Odin (Marvel Cinematic Universe)")'s throne room, where they were greeted by Thor.[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ThorTDWDisneyland-377)_Captain America: The Winter Soldier_'s exhibit, "Captain America: The Living Legend and Symbol of Courage", featured a meet and greet experience.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-CapTWSDisneyland-378)

From May to September 2017, Disneyland Resort featured the "Summer of Heroes", which features members of the Guardians and Avengers appearing throughout the Disneyland Resort. Additionally, the Guardians of the Galaxy: Awesome Dance Off event was featured, which involved [Peter Quill / Star-Lord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Quill_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Quill (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") blasting music from his boombox, along with the Avengers Training Initiative, a limited experience where [Black Widow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natasha_Romanoff_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Natasha Romanoff (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and [Hawkeye](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clint_Barton_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Clint Barton (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") "assemble a group of young recruits to see if they have what it takes to be an Avenger." Marvel-related food and merchandise was also available throughout [Hollywood Land](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood_Land "Hollywood Land") at [Disney California Adventure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure "Disney California Adventure") during the "Summer of Heroes".[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GotGBreakoutOpening-379)

In March 2018, the Walt Disney Company announced three new Marvel-themed areas inspired by the MCU to Disney California Adventure, [Walt Disney Studios Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Paris "Walt Disney Studios Paris"), and [Hong Kong Disneyland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_Disneyland "Hong Kong Disneyland"). The developments were designed by [Walt Disney Imagineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Disney_Imagineering "Walt Disney Imagineering") in collaboration with Marvel Studios and Marvel Themed Entertainment.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380) As was established with [_Guardians of the Galaxy_ – Mission: Breakout!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guardians_of_the_Galaxy_%E2%80%93_Mission:_Breakout! "Guardians of the Galaxy – Mission: Breakout!"), Avengers Campus exists in its own theme park universe that is inspired by the MCU.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GotGBreakoutMCUConnection-381)[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AvengersCampusMultiverse-382) Being in the MCU multiverse, Avengers Campus has a shared history with the MCU proper, with a few notable exceptions being [the Blip](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Blip "The Blip") from _Avengers: Infinity War_ did not occur, and some characters who died, such as Tony Stark, are still alive.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AvengersCampusMultiverse-382)

triples.statement: The exhibit also included smaller displays of helmets and chest pieces from earlier films, as well as the gauntlet and boot from an action sequence in Iron Man 3.

triples.statement: As part of the MCU multiverse, Avengers Campus shares a history with the main MCU, but with notable exceptions, such as the Blip from Avengers: Infinity War not occurring and deceased characters like Tony Stark still being alive.

section_body:
In October 2013, the [Iron Man Experience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Man_Experience "Iron Man Experience") attraction was announced for Hong Kong Disneyland.[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IronManExperience-383) It is set in the [Tomorrowland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomorrowland_(Disney_Parks) "Tomorrowland (Disney Parks)") section of the park,[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpDS-384) with the area built to look like a new Stark Expo created by Tony Stark after the 2010 one, as seen in _Iron Man 2_,[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpStarkExpo-385) with various exhibit halls that include the Mark III armor from the films.[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpDS-384)[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpMKIII-386) The area also has Iron Man and Marvel-themed merchandise items and memorabilia, plus an interactive game where guests can have the chance to try on Iron Man's armor.[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpReleaseDate-387) Iron Man Experience sees guests assist Iron Man in defeating Hydra throughout Hong Kong,[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpDS-384) and opened on January 11, 2017.[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IMExpReleaseDate-387)

In March 2018, the Walt Disney Company announced a new Marvel-themed area inspired by the MCU to Hong Kong Disneyland and a new attraction where guests team up with Ant-Man and the Wasp, to join Iron Man Experience.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380)[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyParksMar2018-388) Inspired by _Ant-Man and the Wasp_,[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AMWaspRide-389)[Ant-Man and The Wasp: Nano Battle!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant-Man_and_The_Wasp:_Nano_Battle! "Ant-Man and The Wasp: Nano Battle!") is an enclosed interactive dark ride that sees guests use laser-powered weapons to team up with Ant-Man and the Wasp to defeat [Arnim Zola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnim_Zola_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Arnim Zola (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and his army of Hydra swarm bots.[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AMWaspRide-389)[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AMWaspRideName-390) Ant Man and the Wasp: Nano Battle! replaces the [Buzz Lightyear Astro Blasters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buzz_Lightyear_attractions "Buzz Lightyear attractions") ride,[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AMWaspRide-389) and opened on March 31, 2019.[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AMWaspRideOpen-391)

section_body:
By San Diego Comic-Con 2016, the [Tower of Terror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Twilight_Zone_Tower_of_Terror "The Twilight Zone Tower of Terror") at Disney California Adventure was set to be replaced by a new attraction, _Guardians of the Galaxy_ – Mission: Breakout!. [Chris Pratt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Pratt "Chris Pratt"), [Zoë Saldaña](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zo%C3%AB_Salda%C3%B1a "Zoë Saldaña"), [Dave Bautista](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Bautista "Dave Bautista") and [Benicio del Toro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benicio_del_Toro "Benicio del Toro") all filmed exclusive footage for the attraction, reprising their roles as [Peter Quill / Star-Lord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Quill_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Quill (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), [Gamora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamora_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Gamora (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), [Drax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drax_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Drax (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and [Taneleer Tivan / The Collector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collector_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Collector (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), respectively.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GotGBreakout-392)[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GotGBreakout2-393) James Gunn, director of _Guardians of the Galaxy_ and its sequel, directed footage for the attraction and consulted on all aspects of it.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GotGBreakoutGunn-394)_Guardians of the Galaxy_ – Mission: Breakout! sees visitors assisting Rocket in rescuing the other Guardians from the Collector's fortress, while the attraction features randomized events throughout the experience and music inspired by the _[Awesome Mix Vol. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guardians\_of\_the\_Galaxy:\_Awesome\_Mix\_Vol.\_1\_(Original\_Motion\_Picture\_Soundtrack) "Guardians of the Galaxy: Awesome Mix Vol. 1 (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)")_ soundtrack. The attraction opened on May 27, 2017.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GotGBreakoutOpening-379)

In March 2018, the Walt Disney Company announced a new Marvel-themed area inspired by the MCU at Disney California Adventure, anchored by Mission: Breakout!, that features characters from the MCU, such as Iron Man and Spider-Man, joining the Guardians of the Galaxy in a "completely immersive superhero universe". The area replaced "[A Bug's Land](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Bug%27s_Land "A Bug's Land")", which closed in mid-2018 to begin construction of the Marvel area.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380)[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyParksMar2018-388)[Tom Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Holland "Tom Holland") reprises his role as [Peter Parker / Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in the attraction [Web Slingers: A Spider-Man Adventure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Slingers:_A_Spider-Man_Adventure "Web Slingers: A Spider-Man Adventure"), in which Parker has set up W.E.B. (the Worldwide Engineers Brigade) to inspire a new generation to use technology to save the world. Riders are recruited by Spider-Man into the initiative to stop his malfunctioning Spider-Bots.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-HollandWebSlingers-395) Web Slingers was directed by _Spider-Man_ director Jon Watts along with Brett Strong, and was written by Steven Spiegel and featured visual effects by [Framestore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Framestore "Framestore").[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-WaittWebSlingers-396) A one-act version of _[Rogers: The Musical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers:\_The\_Musical "Rogers: The Musical")_ premiered at the [Hyperion Theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperion_Theater "Hyperion Theater") on June 30, 2023, and ran for a limited time until August 31.[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-RogersMusicalDCA-397)

section_body: In March 2018, the Walt Disney Company announced a new Marvel-themed area inspired by the MCU to [Disneyland Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disneyland_Paris "Disneyland Paris")' Walt Disney Studios Park. The area includes a reimagined attraction where riders team up with Iron Man and other Avengers on a "hyper-kinetic adventure" on July 20, 2022.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380)[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyParisJuly2022-398) The park also hosted the "Summer of Super Heroes" live-action stage show from June–September 2018.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380)[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyParksMar2018-388)

triples.sentence: The area includes a reimagined attraction where riders team up with Iron Man and other Avengers on a "hyper-kinetic adventure" on July 20, 2022.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380)[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyParisJuly2022-398)
triples.statement: The area includes a reimagined attraction that opened on July 20, 2022, where riders team up with Iron Man and other Avengers on a "hyper-kinetic adventure".

triples.sentence: The park also hosted the "Summer of Super Heroes" live-action stage show from June–September 2018.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietyDisneyParks-380)[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyParksMar2018-388)
triples.statement: The park hosted the "Summer of Super Heroes" live-action stage show from June to September 2018.

section_body:
Main articles: [Disney Wish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_Wish "Disney Wish") and [Disney Treasure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney_Treasure "Disney Treasure")

In July 2021, the immersive family dining experience "**Avengers: Quantum Encounter**" at the Worlds of Marvel restaurant on the _Disney Wish_ cruise ship was announced, which debuted when the cruise began voyages on July 14, 2022.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyWish-399)[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyWishDelay-400) The experience takes place during dinner with interactive elements and a full CGI recreation of the _Wish_'s upper decks.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-QuantumEncounterPolygon-401)[Paul Rudd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Rudd "Paul Rudd"), [Evangeline Lilly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evangeline_Lilly "Evangeline Lilly"), [Anthony Mackie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie"), [Brie Larson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brie_Larson "Brie Larson"), [Kerry Condon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerry_Condon "Kerry Condon"), and [Iman Vellani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iman_Vellani "Iman Vellani") reprised their MCU roles,[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-QuantumEncounter-402)[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VellaniQuantumEncounter-403) while [Ross Marquand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ross_Marquand "Ross Marquand") voiced [Ultron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultron_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Ultron (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") after previously doing so in _[What If...?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What\_If...%3F\_(TV\_series) "What If...? (TV series)")_, in which he replaced [James Spader](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Spader "James Spader").[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-QuantumEncounter-402)[Chris Waitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Waitt "Chris Waitt") directed Rudd and Lilly's content, which was written by Steven Spiegel and featured visual effects by Framestore.[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-WaittQuantumEncounter-404)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-WaittWebsite-405)_The Marvels_ director [Nia DaCosta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nia_DaCosta "Nia DaCosta") filmed Vellani and Larson's content in London ahead of principal photography for the film.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DaCostaQuantumEncounter-406)

In September 2023, the _Wish_'s [sister ship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sister_ship "Sister ship") the _[Disney Treasure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney\_Treasure "Disney Treasure")_ was announced to also include the Worlds of Marvel restaurant with two nights of distinct shows and menus, featuring an appearance by Spider-Man. The Marvel Super Hero Academy is also included on the cruise, where young kids can train to be superheroes with Spider-Man, Black Panther, and Ant-Man. These were available on the _Treasure_ when it began voyages on December 21, 2024.[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DisneyTreasure-407)

section_body:
In May 2014, the _Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N._ (Scientific Training and Tactical Intelligence Operative Network) exhibit opened at the [Discovery Times Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discovery_Times_Square "Discovery Times Square") center. The exhibit features replica set pieces and props from the films, mixed with interactive technology and information, crafted through a partnership with [NASA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA") and other scientists. [Titus Welliver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titus_Welliver "Titus Welliver") also provides a "debrief" to visitors, reprising his role as S.H.I.E.L.D. agent [Felix Blake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felix_Blake "Felix Blake"). Created by Victory Hill Exhibits, _Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N._ cost $7.5 million to create,[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AvengersSTATIONDailyNews-408)[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AvengersSTATIONEW-409) and ran through early September 2015.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-AvengersSTATIONClosing-410)

The exhibit also opened in [South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") at the [War Memorial of Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_Memorial_of_Korea "War Memorial of Korea") in April 2015,[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONKorea-411)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONLasVegas-412) in Paris, France, at [Esplanade de La Défense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esplanade_de_La_D%C3%A9fense_(Paris_M%C3%A9tro) "Esplanade de La Défense (Paris Métro)") a year later, and in Las Vegas at the [Treasure Island Hotel and Casino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treasure_Island_Hotel_and_Casino "Treasure Island Hotel and Casino") in June 2016.[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONLasVegas-412) The Las Vegas version of the exhibit featured updated character details and corresponding science to incorporate the Marvel films that were released since the original exhibit in New York. Additionally, the Las Vegas version features Cobie Smulders reprising her role as Maria Hill to "debrief" visitors, replacing Welliver.[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONLasVegas2-413)

triples.sentence: The exhibit also opened in [South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") at the [War Memorial of Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_Memorial_of_Korea "War Memorial of Korea") in April 2015,[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONKorea-411)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONLasVegas-412) in Paris, France, at [Esplanade de La Défense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esplanade_de_La_D%C3%A9fense_(Paris_M%C3%A9tro) "Esplanade de La Défense (Paris Métro)") a year later, and in Las Vegas at the [Treasure Island Hotel and Casino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treasure_Island_Hotel_and_Casino "Treasure Island Hotel and Casino") in June 2016.[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONLasVegas-412)
triples.statement: The exhibit also opened in South Korea in April 2015, in Paris a year later, and in Las Vegas in June 2016.

triples.sentence: Additionally, the Las Vegas version features Cobie Smulders reprising her role as Maria Hill to "debrief" visitors, replacing Welliver.[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-STATIONLasVegas2-413)
triples.statement: The Las Vegas version features Cobie Smulders reprising her role as Maria Hill to "debrief" visitors, replacing Titus Welliver.

section_body: An art exhibit, titled _Marvel: Creating the Cinematic Universe_, was displayed exclusively at the [Queensland Gallery of Modern Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensland_Gallery_of_Modern_Art "Queensland Gallery of Modern Art") (GOMA) in Brisbane, Australia, in 2017. The exhibit, which included "300 plus objects, films, costumes, drawings and other ephemera", featured content "from the collection of Marvel Studios and Marvel Entertainment and private collections" with "significant focus [given] to the creative artists who translate the drawn narrative to the screen through production design and storyboarding, costume and prop design, and special effects and post-production". _Marvel: Creating the Cinematic Universe_ was also extended to GOMA's Australian Cinémathèque with a retrospective of the MCU films.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GOMA-414)[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GOMASMH-415)

triples.sentence: _Marvel: Creating the Cinematic Universe_ was also extended to GOMA's Australian Cinémathèque with a retrospective of the MCU films.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GOMA-414)[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-GOMASMH-415)
triples.statement: The "Marvel: Creating the Cinematic Universe" exhibit was extended to GOMA's Australian Cinémathèque, which featured a retrospective of the MCU films.

section_body: In October 2019, Marvel Studios and [ILMxLAB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ILMxLAB "ILMxLAB") announced the [virtual reality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality "Virtual reality") experience _Avengers: Damage Control_. The experience was available for a limited time starting in mid-October 2019 at select [Void VR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Void_(virtual_reality) "The Void (virtual reality)") locations. _Avengers: Damage Control_ sees players taking control of one of Shuri's Emergency Response Suits–which combine Wakandan and Stark Industries technologies–to defeat a threat alongside Doctor Strange, Ant-Man, and the Wasp. [Letitia Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letitia_Wright "Letitia Wright"), [Benedict Cumberbatch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedict_Cumberbatch "Benedict Cumberbatch"), [Paul Rudd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Rudd "Paul Rudd"), and [Evangeline Lilly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evangeline_Lilly "Evangeline Lilly") all reprise their MCU roles,[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VRDamageControl-416) while Ross Marquand voices Ultron, replacing James Spader.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MarquandDC-417) The experience was extended to the end of 2019.[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VRDamageControlExtended-418)

triples.statement: The experience was extended to the end of 2019.

section_path: Marvel Studios' Infinity Saga Concert Experience
section_body: In May 2024, the Marvel Studios' Infinity Saga Concert Experience was announced by Disney Concerts, Marvel Studios, and the [Los Angeles Philharmonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Philharmonic "Los Angeles Philharmonic"), to premiere on August 30 and 31, 2024, at the [Hollywood Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood_Bowl "Hollywood Bowl"). The concert, conducted by the Philharmonic's Music and Artistic director [Gustavo Dudamel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustavo_Dudamel "Gustavo Dudamel"), features the Philharmonic performing a "specially created score" of music from the Infinity Saga films, such as _The Avengers_ theme and "[Portals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_assemble_scene#Music "Avengers assemble scene")" from _Avengers: Endgame_, live to picture.[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ConcertExperience-419) The first half of the concert focused on individual characters from the films, while the second half centered on _Avengers: Infinity War_ and _Avengers: Endgame_. A "post-credits scene" saw the Philharmonic play [Michael Giacchino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Giacchino "Michael Giacchino")'s theme from _[The Fantastic Four: First Steps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Fantastic\_Four:\_First\_Steps "The Fantastic Four: First Steps")_ (2025).[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ConcertExperienceTour-420) The performance also used [projection mapping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projection_mapping "Projection mapping") on the proscenium of the Hollywood Bowl while audiences members wore [PixMob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PixMob "PixMob") light-up wrist bands.[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ConcertExperience-419)[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ConcertExperienceTour2-421) The concert is set to go on tour globally in 2025.[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ConcertExperienceTour-420)[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ConcertExperienceTour2-421)

section_body: On March 18, 2014, ABC aired a one-hour [television special](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_special "Television special") titled _Marvel Studios: Assembling a Universe_, which documented the history of Marvel Studios and the development of the Marvel Cinematic Universe and included exclusive interviews and behind-the-scenes footage from all of the films, One-Shots, and _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._, and sneak peeks of _Avengers: Age of Ultron_, _Captain America: The Winter Soldier_, _Guardians of the Galaxy_, unaired episodes of _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._,[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-TVSpecial-422) and _Ant-Man_.[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-TVSpecialAntMan-423) Brian Lowry of _Variety_ felt the special, "contains a pretty interesting business and creative story. While it might all make sense in hindsight, there was appreciable audacity in Marvel's plan to release five loosely connected movies from the same hero-filled world, beginning with the cinematically unproven _Iron Man_ and culminating with superhero team _The Avengers_. As such, this fast-moving hour qualifies as more than just a cut-and-paste job from electronic press kits, although there's an element of that, certainly."[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpecialReview-424) The special was released on September 9, 2014, on the home media for _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._ season 1.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SHIELDS1HomeMedia-425)

triples.statement: On March 18, 2014, ABC aired a one-hour television special titled "Marvel Studios: Assembling a Universe," which documented the history of Marvel Studios and the MCU and included sneak peeks of various projects.

triples.sentence: Brian Lowry of _Variety_ felt the special, "contains a pretty interesting business and creative story. While it might all make sense in hindsight, there was appreciable audacity in Marvel's plan to release five loosely connected movies from the same hero-filled world, beginning with the cinematically unproven _Iron Man_ and culminating with superhero team _The Avengers_. As such, this fast-moving hour qualifies as more than just a cut-and-paste job from electronic press kits, although there's an element of that, certainly."[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpecialReview-424)
triples.statement: Brian Lowry of Variety reviewed the special, noting it told an interesting business and creative story about Marvel's audacious plan to connect its films, and that it was more than just a promotional piece.

triples.sentence: The special was released on September 9, 2014, on the home media for _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._ season 1.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SHIELDS1HomeMedia-425)
triples.statement: The special was released on September 9, 2014, as part of the home media for the first season of Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

section_body: In September 2014, _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._ executive producer Jeffrey Bell stated that to meet production demands and avoid having to air repeat episodes, ABC would likely air a Marvel special in place of a regular installment at some point during the first ten episodes of _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._'s second season.[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-BellSep2014-426) In October, the special was revealed to be _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!_, which was hosted by [Emily VanCamp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emily_VanCamp "Emily VanCamp"), who portrays [Agent 13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharon_Carter_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Sharon Carter (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in _Captain America: The Winter Soldier_, and aired on November 4, 2014.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-PulptoPop-427) The special features behind the scenes footage from _Avengers: Age of Ultron_ and _Ant-Man_, as well as footage from the _Agent Carter_ television series previously screened at [New York Comic Con](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Comic_Con "New York Comic Con").[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNSpecial2Review-428) Brian Lowry of _Variety_ felt an hour for the special did not "do the topic justice" adding, "For anyone who has seen more than one Marvel movie but would shrug perplexedly at the mention of Jack Kirby or [Steve Ditko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ditko "Steve Ditko"), _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp To Pop!_ should probably be required viewing. Fun, fast-paced and encompassing many of the company's highlights along with a few lowlights, it's a solid primer on Marvel's history, while weaving in inevitable self-promotion and synergistic plugs."[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpecial2Review-429) Eric Goldman of IGN also wished the special had been longer, adding, "Understandably, the more you already know about Marvel, the less you'll be surprised by _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!_, but it's important to remember who this special is really made for – a mainstream audience who have embraced the Marvel characters, via the hugely successful movies, in a way no one could have imagined."[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNSpecial2Review-428)

triples.sentence: In September 2014, _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._ executive producer Jeffrey Bell stated that to meet production demands and avoid having to air repeat episodes, ABC would likely air a Marvel special in place of a regular installment at some point during the first ten episodes of _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._'s second season.[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-BellSep2014-426)
triples.statement: In September 2014, _Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D._ executive producer Jeffrey Bell stated that ABC would likely air a Marvel special during the show's second season to avoid airing repeat episodes.

triples.sentence: In October, the special was revealed to be _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!_, which was hosted by [Emily VanCamp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emily_VanCamp "Emily VanCamp"), who portrays [Agent 13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharon_Carter_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Sharon Carter (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in _Captain America: The Winter Soldier_, and aired on November 4, 2014.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-PulptoPop-427)
triples.statement: The special, revealed in October to be _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!_, was hosted by Emily VanCamp, who portrays Agent 13, and it aired on November 4, 2014.

triples.sentence: The special features behind the scenes footage from _Avengers: Age of Ultron_ and _Ant-Man_, as well as footage from the _Agent Carter_ television series previously screened at [New York Comic Con](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Comic_Con "New York Comic Con").[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNSpecial2Review-428)
triples.statement: The special featured behind-the-scenes footage from _Avengers: Age of Ultron_ and _Ant-Man_, as well as footage from the _Agent Carter_ television series that had been previously screened at New York Comic Con.

triples.sentence: Brian Lowry of _Variety_ felt an hour for the special did not "do the topic justice" adding, "For anyone who has seen more than one Marvel movie but would shrug perplexedly at the mention of Jack Kirby or [Steve Ditko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ditko "Steve Ditko"), _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp To Pop!_ should probably be required viewing. Fun, fast-paced and encompassing many of the company's highlights along with a few lowlights, it's a solid primer on Marvel's history, while weaving in inevitable self-promotion and synergistic plugs."[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VarietySpecial2Review-429)
triples.statement: Brian Lowry of Variety felt the one-hour special was too short but described it as a fun, fast-paced primer on Marvel's history that should be required viewing for fans unfamiliar with creators like Jack Kirby or Steve Ditko.

triples.sentence: Eric Goldman of IGN also wished the special had been longer, adding, "Understandably, the more you already know about Marvel, the less you'll be surprised by _Marvel 75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!_, but it's important to remember who this special is really made for – a mainstream audience who have embraced the Marvel characters, via the hugely successful movies, in a way no one could have imagined."[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-IGNSpecial2Review-428)
triples.statement: Eric Goldman of IGN also wished the special had been longer, noting it was made for a mainstream audience familiar with the Marvel movies rather than for those who already knew a lot about Marvel.

section_body: The special _Expanding the Universe_ was released on Disney+ on November 12, 2019. It features a look at the original MCU TV series for Disney+, with interviews and concept art.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-ExpandingTheUniverse-430)

section_body: A Marvel-themed orchestra performance of an extended version of [Brian Tyler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Tyler "Brian Tyler")'s Marvel Studios theme and [Alan Silvestri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Silvestri "Alan Silvestri")'s theme from _The Avengers_ took place during China's Bilibili New Year's Gala on December 31, 2020, to promote the 2021 Marvel Studios film releases.[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-BilibiliPerformance-431)[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-BilibiliPerformance2-432)

section_body:
Main article: [_Marvel Studios: Assembled_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Studios:_Assembled "Marvel Studios: Assembled")

Announced in February 2021, each special of the documentary series goes behind the scenes of the making of the MCU films and television series with cast members and additional creatives. _Marvel Studios: Assembled_ premiered on Disney+ on March 12, 2021, with the release of the first special, followed by additional specials.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-Assembled-438)

triples.sentence: _Marvel Studios: Assembled_ premiered on Disney+ on March 12, 2021, with the release of the first special, followed by additional specials.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-Assembled-438)
triples.statement: _Marvel Studios: Assembled_ premiered on Disney+ on March 12, 2021, with its first special, and was followed by additional specials.

section_path: _Voices Rising: The Music of Wakanda Forever_ (2023)
section_body:
Further information: [_Black Panther: Wakanda Forever_ § Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Panther:_Wakanda_Forever#Music "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever")

_Voices Rising: The Music of Wakanda Forever_ is a three-part documentary series detailing the creation process of _Black Panther: Wakanda Forever_'s soundtrack. It premiered on Disney+ on February 28, 2023.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VoicesRisingMarvel-439) The documentary series was originally scheduled to be removed from Disney+ on May 26, 2023, as part of Disney's efforts to reduce content costs, but ultimately was decided to remain on the service at that time.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DocsPlannedD+Removal-440)

triples.sentence: It premiered on Disney+ on February 28, 2023.[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-VoicesRisingMarvel-439)
triples.statement: The series premiered on Disney+ on February 28, 2023.

triples.sentence: The documentary series was originally scheduled to be removed from Disney+ on May 26, 2023, as part of Disney's efforts to reduce content costs, but ultimately was decided to remain on the service at that time.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DocsPlannedD+Removal-440)
triples.statement: The documentary series was initially scheduled for removal from Disney+ on May 26, 2023, to reduce content costs, but the decision was reversed and it remained on the service.

section_body:
In June 2021, Marvel Studios released a casting call for fans of "Marvel's strong women" to be a part of an unscripted Disney+ documentary series showcasing the women who create the MCU in front of and behind the camera, including actors and creatives, and the fans who applied to participate in the series.[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-SuperWomenCasting-441) The series was titled _MPower_ by February 2023 and premiered in its entirety on March 8, 2023,[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPower-442) consisting of four episodes titled "The Women of Black Panther", "Captain Marvel", "Scarlet Witch", and "Gamora",[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerComicBookDetails-443) which were directed by Quinn Wilson and used [archival footage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archival_footage "Archival footage") and animation.[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerComicBookDetails-443)[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerMarvelDetails-444) Its release coincided with [International Women's Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day "International Women's Day").[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerSRBWInsult-445) Several MCU actresses were interviewed to discuss what makes their characters compelling to audiences, including [Danai Gurira](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danai_Gurira "Danai Gurira"), [Lupita Nyong'o](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lupita_Nyong%27o "Lupita Nyong'o"), [Florence Kasumba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Kasumba "Florence Kasumba"), and Letitia Wright; Brie Larson, Iman Vellani, and [Teyonah Parris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teyonah_Parris "Teyonah Parris"); [Elizabeth Olsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Olsen "Elizabeth Olsen"), [Kathryn Hahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kathryn_Hahn "Kathryn Hahn"), and [Kat Dennings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kat_Dennings "Kat Dennings"); and Zoë Saldaña,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerComicBookDetails-443) who executive produced the series alongside Victoria Alonso. Saldaña said the series was a tribute to the representation and empowerment of women with the intent to "ignite meaningful conversations and drive real change towards a more equal and inclusive world."[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerComicBookDetails-443)[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerMarvelInterview-446)[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerMarvelDetails-444) Other creatives who were interviewed for episodes include Marvel Studios executive [Trinh Tran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinh_Tran "Trinh Tran"), _Black Panther_ costume designer [Ruth E. Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_E._Carter "Ruth E. Carter"), production designer [Hannah Beachler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hannah_Beachler "Hannah Beachler"), and editor [Debbie Berman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debbie_Berman "Debbie Berman").[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPower/FilmDetails-447) The documentary series was originally scheduled to be removed from Disney+ on May 26, 2023, as part of Disney's efforts to reduce content costs, but ultimately was decided to remain on the service at that time.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-DocsPlannedD+Removal-440) The series was produced by [Herzog & Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herzog_%26_Co. "Herzog & Co."), Saldaña's production company [Cinestar Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinestar_Pictures "Cinestar Pictures"), and [Just Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Just_Entertainment "Just Entertainment").[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerMarvelDetails-444)[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerMarvelInterview-446)

Aaron Perine at _[ComicBook.com](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ComicBook.com "ComicBook.com")_ believed that the series would have "something for all fans to enjoy" with each character's entry because of the fan appreciation,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerComicBookDetails-443) while BJ Conagelo of _[/Film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki//Film "/Film")_ stated it was "fantastic to see a thoughtful and in-depth spotlight" of the work by diverse groups of women in the MCU, and found it was "equally as impressive" how much the series analyzed their impact as a "sincere assessment" of the importance of the stories beyond [gender representation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_representation "Gender representation").[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPower/FilmDetails-447) Philip Watson at _CGMagazine_ said that while the series seemed focused on "add[ing] depth" to the backstories of the females behind Marvel, a secondary focus was to honor the title and empower women, quoting Kasumba: "You could watch it and think 'people that look like me, we can be Super Heroes too'".[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerCGMagazineDetails-448) Kai Young of _Screen Rant_ felt that the series' exclusion of an episode focused on [Scarlett Johansson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarlett_Johansson "Scarlett Johansson")'s MCU character Natasha Romanoff / Black Widow was another "insult against" the character as she was "pivotal to the MCU", and had wanted such an episode to focus on developing Romanoff as an individual beyond her relationships with male characters and alongside her family.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe#cite_note-MPowerSRBWInsult-445)
